event.title: was granted land here by the leader of Acadia, Isaac de Razilly (c. 1632

data.event: Later Nicolas Denys, a pioneering 17th-century French explorer and trader of Nova Scotia, was granted land here by the leader of Acadia, Isaac de Razilly (c. 1632).

event.title: was founded by New England Planters (commercially organized settlers) as a fishing port in 1759

data.event: Following the Expulsion of the Acadians during the French and Indian War (1754–1763), Liverpool was founded by New England Planters (commercially organized settlers) as a fishing port in 1759, originally named Lingley after Admiral Charles Lingley, and then renamed after Liverpool in England – which also lies along its own Mersey River.
In 1759 Capt. Cobb became a proprietor of the new township of Liverpool.

event.title: July 1, 1760, at the first meeting of the proprietors, Capt. Cobb made

data.event: On July 1, 1760, at the first meeting of the proprietors, Capt. Cobb made a petition to be granted a piece of land to build a house and a wharf.
